projects.title: Untitled Voxel Engine
projects.description: Javascript voxel game engine I am currently working on. In its current form, it has infinite procedural terrain generation using perlin noise and automatic chunk re-meshing whenever a chunk is edited.

projects.title: ItemBuilder Studio
projects.description:
Web interface for a Minecraft datapack I created. (See the 'Minecraft' tab for more info.) It is a user-friendly interface to create the recursive JSON structures that define item behavior in my datapack. Create effects for the items and conditions that must take place for those effects to happen. Mix and match any way you like to create your custom items.

Created in React.js.

projects.title: SongSketchStudio
projects.description:
SongSketchStudio is a web app for sketching out songs with your friends and/or bandmates in real time using concurrent editing! Create simple compositions fast so your band can start playing them right away.

You have two main views: The part view and the arrangement view. The part view lets you place notes at various times and select different instruments. The arrangement view lets you arrange the various parts together to create a full song. Both views have a player that lets you listen to your song in its current state.

The app has a login/account system to protect parts and songs against unauthorized access. You can also invite friends to work on parts with you, granting them access.

Developed using express.js with MongoDB for the backend and vanilla Javascript for the frontend. This was my Capstone Project for my Bachelor's Degree.

projects.title: Mobile MIDI
projects.description:
Mobile MIDI is a mobile app for using your phone as a gyroscopic MIDI controller. You can tilt your phone left and right to select notes and press on the bottom half of the screen to play them until you release your finger. It has many options for customizing the available MIDI controls and how the controller will respond to various actions. You can set it up to play basic piano sounds or you can plug it into a MIDI device (such as a synthesizer) and control it.

Developed for my mobile development class in college. Written in Flutter.

projects.title: PlayBuddy
projects.description:
PlayBuddy is a web app for finding ongoing and upcoming events in your local area. It features the ability to post new events and filter events by date and proximity. The proximity filter uses a dataset of zip codes to determine distance.

Developed for my software engineering class in college on a team of five people. I did most of the backend, which was made in express.js.

projects.title: Let's Meet
projects.description:
Let's Meet is a simple web app for agreeing on a time to hold a meetup. The host can select available dates and times from a calendar and participants can select when they are available from those times. The calendar has a heatmap visualization to show which times are the most available and will specially mark times where everyone is available.

Developed for my web development class in college on a team of two. Written in Django.

projects.title: Dominion Card Generator
projects.description:
Fine-tuned GPT-2 model that generates card designs for the board game Dominion. I grabbed a raw table of cards from the Dominion wiki and used a Python script to reformat it to be more human-readable and shuffle the data. The model was trained on this data using Huggingface's Transformer library.

The examples on the right were cherry-picked from a total of four 1000-token batches, then were recreated using shardofhonor's Dominion card image generator.

projects.title: Voxel Transformer Experiment
projects.description:
VoxelGPT is a project with the goal of training a transformer model from scratch to generate Voxel-based 3D sculptures and add onto existing ones.

In order to provide proper context for nearby Voxels, VoxelGPT uses a special version of positional encoding that takes into account the voxel's xyz position in space. Each color is represented by an index from a limited color palette. The model picks from one of these colors (including air) as its output.

The training example sculptures are stored in .vox format. I then convert them to json and perform data augmentation by shifting their color. (I plan in the future to also perform random transformations.) Voxels are then encoded using their hsv values as well as their xyz spatial position.

I am as of yet unable to get the model to learn complex patterns. While it can learn very simple patterns (like recreating a single sculpture from the training data), it is unable to generate brand new sculptures. I theorize this is due to an insufficient number of training examples and I am currently looking into ways to obtain/generate more.

Implemented using Tensorflow and Keras.

projects.title: ML Calculator
projects.description: A simple experiment in training a network to add four-digit numbers encoded using one-hot vectors. The goal was to build understanding in how much network capacity is needed for logical tasks. The training and test examples are generated on the fly. The smallest I could get the model while maintaining 100% accuracy was 1 hidden layer with 600 neurons and then 5 hidden layers with 180 neurons each. Implemented using Tensorflow and Keras.

projects.title: Generative Collaborative Network Experiment
projects.description: Sprite Maker was an experiment in generative collaborative networks with human feedback. The goal was to let a user generate pixel images by giving feedback to a model that trains in real time. The premise was to have two networks: The generator and the judge. The user would rate images generated by the generator from one to five stars. This rating would then be used as a training example for the judge, which, given an image, would try to guess what star rating the user gave it. The generator would then try to generate images that score highly from the judge by backpropogating through the judge in a similar manner to GAN's. The main problem was that choosing the better of two random pixel noise images is rather difficult since it's rare that either of them will look enough like the target image for the rating to be meaningful. Additionally, the generator model would become far too focused on recreating any image that was rated positively by the user. Although the latter problem might be solved by limiting the generator's learning rate. Implemented using Tensorflow and Keras.

projects.title: Girl Gossip: Revelations
projects.description:
GMTK 2025 Jam Entry. Placed 120th in creativity, 145th in audio, and 232nd in narrative out of 9657 total submissions.

Find out what your friends are saying behind your back! Manipulate their every action, study their every move, and hear their every word! Place hidden microphones and parse half-heard, half-said conversations to deduce information to record in your Gossip Diary. Then change the layout of the party and repeat!

Made by myself and nephguy, with voice acting by him and our friends.

links.text: Play the game in browser here

projects.title: AM I ORTHODOX?
projects.description:
Ludum Dare 57 Jam Entry. Placed 34th overall, 2nd in innovation, and 10th in mood out of 1181 total submissions.

A puzzle game where you ask questions using a limited set of words to unlock more words and uncover the truth about who you are.

Music by Wyatt Cannon.

links.text: Play the game in browser here

projects.title: Growbot
projects.description:
GMTK 2024 Jam entry. 

A puzzle-platformer Metroidvania about growing plants. Explore the cavern for new tools and plants. Then use your tools to build automated farms and generate money!

links.text: Play the game in browser here

projects.title: And Don't Open Your Mouth Again
projects.description:
Ludum Dare 55 Jam Entry.

And Don’t Open Your Mouth Again is a logical deduction text adventure game. Ten people have answered their jury summons in order to decide the fate of a man accused of first degree murder and assaulting a police officer. Your job is to interview the jurors and read their deliberations to deduce which combination of the four of them will deliver a verdict of not guilty!

This is a very experimental game that makes use of semi-procedural dialogue. Different jurors will take the deliberations in different directions by having different responses to certain arguments or questions.

links.text: Play the game in browser here

projects.title: Air-Raid Architect
projects.description:
Ludum Dare 54 Jam Entry. Placed 154th overall, 135th in fun, and 94th in innovation out of 1597 total submissions.

Take to the skies in this voxel-based arena shooter! Fight killer wasps who want to tear down your sky fortress. After each round of enemies, you can spend collected wasp-honey to build new structures.

Made on a team with Groverburger using my custom voxel engine.

links.text: Play the game in browser here (Chrome recommended)

projects.title: You Are Person Guy
projects.description:
GMTK 2023 Jam entry. Placed 472nd overall and 75th in enjoyment out of 6842 total submissions.

A puzzle game where you can mind control your enemies. Control six different enemy types with unique abilities: Golem Guy, Fire Guy, Water Guy, Wind Guy, Ice Guy, and Vine Guy. Contains 25 challenging levels!

Made on a team with Groverburger using his custom javascript game engine. He did the visual design, sound design, and menus while I did the mechanics programming, level design, and music.

links.text: Play the game in browser here

projects.title: Sorting Center Savant
projects.description:
Ludum Dare 53 Compo entry. Placed 18th overall, 19th in fun, and 12th in innovation out of 491 total submissions.

A puzzle game where you must sort boxes into the correct chute using color-coded machinery. Each color has one control that activates all of the machinery of that color, requiring careful ordering of moves. It has 12 challenging levels to play and support for custom levels.

links.text: Play the game in browser here

projects.title: Organ-ized Crime
projects.description:
Ludum Dare 52 Jam entry. Placed 77th overall and 25th in humor out of 1144 total submissions.

It’s great to volunteer to donate your organs. It’s even better to volunteer someone else. In this first-person puzzle game, you harvest organs by finding a "donor", leading them to a secluded area, and tranquilizing them. The trick is that not every resident of Darksville will have suitably healthy organs for your client, so you must vet your targets first.

links.text: Play the game in browser here

projects.title: Starshot
projects.description:
Ludum Dare 51 Jam entry.

In this first-person shooter/parkour game, you have ten seconds to reach the end of a series of procedurally generated levels.

Made on a team with Groverburger using his custom javascript game engine. Groverburger did most of the gameplay while I did the procedural generation. It uses layered cellular automata to create random caves and the diamond-square algorithm to create terrain. It then chooses a random start and end point and uses Dijkstra's algorithm to find the shortest traversable path between the two so it can mark the path for the player. (If none can be found, it will carve a straight trench between a random point reachable from the start and a random point that can reach the end.) Then if the path is too long to reach (decided by the difficulty of the level), it will move the flag farther forward. The towers found in every fifth level are created by a generation algorithm of my own design which prefers to create buildings that twist back around toward themselves.

links.text: Play the game in browser here

title: Quake Level Design and Modding
description: Levels and other projects I have created for id Software's 1996 first person shooter game.

projects.title: LibreQuake Singleplayer Maps
projects.description:
Singleplayer maps I made for the LibreQuake project.

e1m1 - Rats Behind Bars - A trainyard and military base. Co-created by aDaya.
e1m2 - The Feudal Anomaly - A multi-level castle that introduces the player to the game's mechanics and enemy types.
e1m3 - Rogue's Passage - A dark dungeon with tricky combat in tight areas.
e1m4 - Dismal Shores - A lakeside castle with a weaving, self-intersecting structure.
e1m5 - Gloomliths - Two monolithic fortresses filled with secrets and alternate paths.
e4m1 - Damnation Station - An underground base where the player has a choice between two weapons.

projects.title: LibreQuake Deathmatch Maps
projects.description:
Thirteen deathmatch maps I made for the LibreQuake project.

lqdm1 - Solstice - A small winter castle map designed to be an easy to understand warm-up map for players to load into by default.
lqdm2 - Torture Pit - A vertically stacked dungeon designed around the game's lower-tier weapons.
lqdm3 - Hyperborea - A greek temple with jump pads.
lqdm4 - Psychofuge - An outdoor lava fortress with strong items in the dangerous lower areas.
lqdm5 - Transport Tubes - A factory yard with locking air tubes that carry the player around the map.
lqdm6 - Ghost Quarter - A castle map where weapons and armor types unlock over the course of the match.
lqdm7 - Boomstick Basement - A claustrophobic map with lots of winding tunnels and alternate routes.
lqdm8 - Alichar Sector - A very vertical map with a tall elevator that players must ride to access the red armor.
lqdm9 - The Outlands - A Mayan temple map with special doors that can only be opened with the grenade launcher weapon.
lqdm10 - Lucifer's Gambit - A temple map with lava and interesting verticality.
lqdm11 - The Wicked Night - A base map built around a central nexus.
lqdm12 - Javelin - A map with a respawning key players can use to permanently unlock new rooms and powerups.
lqdm13 - Death Provides No Return - A void map with lots of jump pads.

projects.title: Ulgreth's Labyrinth
projects.description:
SM219 speedmap made in 4 days with a limit of 40 monsters or fewer. I had always intended to make puzzle-oriented Quake map and this speedmap event seemed like the perfect opportunity. In this level, you must avoid combat and manipulate the environment to deal with monsters in other ways.

I purposely used Death Knights as the first few enemies the player encounters, since they are particularly difficult to kill with only the Axe. This teaches the player to look for alternate avenues to get past obstacles.

links.text: Watch a playthrough by Greenwood here

projects.title: Devil Monster / The Fuse is Lit
projects.description:
As my submission to the second community Modding Jam, I made a custom monster called the Devil. It is a completely original monster start-to-finish with custom modeling, animations, skinning, and AI. It was made with three design goals in mind:
1) To pose a credible threat to the player even when it has the low ground.
2) To be able to hit the player from unique angles, including from behind other monsters.
3) To not chase the player directly and instead try to keep its distance.

The Fuse is Lit was the demo map I packaged in with my submission to show off the new enemy. It was designed to show off the monster's unique capabilities in a multitude of different ways while still playing like a classic Quake level should.

links.text: Watch a playthrough by Greenwood here

projects.title: SM216 / The Rocket Crusade
projects.description:
I hosted the SM216 speedmap event based on an original premise: The first two days of the event were spent just making level textures, then the remainder of the event was spent making the map using only the level textures contributed in the first part. Six maps were submitted with textures made by ten people.

The map I submitted was called The Rocket Crusade. I continued my fascination with open-ended level design by making a map where you choose your own start point. The level begins with you shooting out of a cannon to land anywhere on the castle you wish. Then you must explore the castle, scrounging for powerups, weapons, and keys. The castle is gigantic and has tons of nooks and crannies to explore. I am particularly proud of the placement of the secrets, which reward the player for paying attention to the level structure and trying to access esoteric parts of the level geometry.

links.text: Watch a playthrough by QuakeFreak here

projects.title: An Even Worse Place
projects.description:
Snack Pack 2 speedmap made in two days. I took inspiration from another mapmaker called Pinchy, who is known for making very open-ended and difficult maps. The design goal was to have a map that's very difficult but you learn how to navigate it better and better with each attempt.

There are several areas that you don't necessarily have to visit in order to win, but they have items you may want. It is up to the player to decide which areas are worth visiting by balancing the difficulty of those areas and the potential waste of timed powerups with the additional benefit of the items found there.

links.text: Watch a playthrough by The Lost Slipgate here

projects.title: SM205 / The Infinite Garage
projects.description:
I hosted the SM205 speedmap event with the premise that participants are given restrictions for their map from a randomizer Python script I wrote. The randomizer tells the participant which entities they must use plus an additional special requirement.

The map I submitted was called The Infinite Garage. It's a total gimmick map that takes place on a grid of openable and closeable doors. I got the requirement of 8 Explosive Crates. When brainstorming ideas, I thought of using them to trigger shootable buttons. That eventually evolved into this map. The player carves their way through until they find both keys and the exit. The unofficial secret goal is to open every door in the level, a task that has a certain catharsis to it.

links.text: Try out the randomizer script here
Watch a playthrough by JCR here

projects.title: Downfire
projects.description:
SM198 speedmap made in about two weeks with the limitation that the map could be no more than 768x768 units wide horizontally. The map could, however, be as tall as it wanted. In fact, my map takes up the entire vertical space a Quake map is allowed without expanded limits.

The map is essentially one long "Romero Lift" (a slow moving platform that you must ride while monsters drop in from above.) It constantly spawns new enemies above the player that they must fend off until the laser-grid floor lowers down to next checkpoint. All the while, the level geometry is changing as new obstacles phase through the floor and into the immediate playable space. In order to pace the level out, the elevator stops twice during the level. The player must go through a teleporter taking them to a side room where they must press a switch that re-enables the elevator. These side rooms are much slower paced in order to give the player a break from the frantic action of the elevator sections.

The third and final section of the elevator makes the greatest use of the changing obstacles by making the level constantly morph and shift until a well-timed Quad Damage drops from the ceiling. At the end, the level splits into four divided sections while monsters continue to spawn in the other three. The monsters continue to build up until the walls disappear completely and the player must fight all of them with their waning Quad Damage.

This is my favorite level I have designed for Quake.

links.text: Download the updated version from Epochs of Enmity here
Watch a playthrough by Andrew Yoder here

projects.title: The Dredge Arena
projects.description: An attempt to bring Mario-64 Collectathon style gameplay to Quake. The Dredge Arena is the only finished map made for my scrapped Bullet Ride mod. It uses nonlinear gameplay to promote exploration through the level to find different runes. There are nine runes to find and many of them have multiple methods to obtain them.

links.text: Watch a playthrough by JCR here

projects.title: Coffee Quake
projects.description:
I co-hosted the Coffee Quake community event. The premise was that each map must be made in under two hours. Mapmakers could spend those two hours whenever they wanted over a three day period, and could even make multiple submissions, but each map could only have two hours spent on it. 76 maps were submitted in total. My job was to decide the order for each map, recompile them to link the maps together, and fix any bugs.

I ended up creating eight maps as submissions. The Mortal Coil, Starship Cthon, Top of the Castle, Spires Aplenty, Damnation Portals, Bosium Loops, Runeforge, and Curse of Shallow Graves.

That last map contained an innovation I still use today. Teleporting monsters into the map is a real pain since you have to set up a trigger, a teleporter, and a teleport destination, all of which need unique and correctly linked names. Curse of Shallow Graves teleports tons of monsters into the level by lining them up on a moving platform outside the map that slowly slides into a teleporter. That way, the monsters get teleported in one by one as they reach the teleporter.

projects.title: Crimson Consequence
projects.description: SM195 speedmap made in 24 hours. It is the first Quake map I have released. The map is very simple in its structure, essentially being a playground of twelve different base ideas. It gives the player a lot of freedom on how they want to navigate it and even spawns the player in a central room containing four powerups to use at their leisure.

links.text: Watch a playthrough by JCR here

title: Minecraft Projects
description: Projects I've made for Minecraft, the 2011 Voxel Game

projects.title: The Escher Dimension
projects.description:
The Escher Dimension is a survival Complete The Monument map built into a datapack. The datapack procedurally generates sixteen dungeons for the player to explore and fight their way through. It includes custom monster designs, custom items, and a full achievement tree.

I worked on this project regularly for almost a year. It is definitely the largest-scale hobby project I have ever finished.

Currently has **escher_downloads** downloads.

links.text: Watch a playthrough by BSM here

projects.title: ItemBuilder / ItemBuilder Studio
projects.description:
ItemBuilder is a datapack/devkit for Minecraft mapmakers that allows the design of custom items using a system of effects and conditions. You can define a recursive JSON structure in item data to make the item have certain effects but only under certain conditions. The logic is designed to be freeform enough to make a wide variety of common item designs possible while still being very user-friendly if using ItemBuilder Studio.

ItemBuilder Studio is a React website that generates item /give commands for ItemBuilder. Since the recursive JSON structure can be a real pain to write by hand, this website makes things easy with convenient dropdowns and a much more appealing way to visualize the logic. It also includes other useful features for custom item design.

A previous version of the website was made using Flutter. It was scrapped for the 2.0 version of ItemBuilder because Flutter's web export is very poorly optimized and I wanted to learn React.

title: Team Fortress 2 Level Design
description: Maps and other assets I have created for the 2007 team shooter game Team Fortress 2.

projects.title: Watercourse
projects.description: Watercourse is a 3CP Attack/Defend map with a river running all the way through it. It takes place in a water De-Purification plant, where they squeeze out drinkable bottles of water to Re-Purify and Re-Bottle it later down the line.

projects.title: WATMM Competition Submissions
projects.description:
These are the submissions I have made to the We Are the Music Makers monthly themed competition. They're not mixed very well since I was (and still am) pretty new to audio mixing and production. All live instruments are played by myself. All other instruments are MIDI.

My favorite tracks of the collection are The Spring Market Carnival, Hill Top Zone, and The Tin Street Busker.
